leukocytosis. UA was done and UCx was done which grew GNRs.

increased to 0.55 and 0.59. Cardiology was consulted and he was 
started on aspirin, Lipitor, metoprolol, and heparin gtt. Repeat 
EKG was similar to prior with no dynamic changes.

Patient was also noted to have delirium, has known baseline 
dementia. He was noted to sundown daily but confusion had 
resolved prior to transfer per discharge summary.

IMAGING:
Percutaneous nephrostomy placement ___:
FINDINGS: 
Mild right-sided hydronephrosis.  Reasonably prompt drainage 
from the ureter with no evidence distal obstruction. 
IMPRESSION: 
Successful placement of 8.5 ___ nephrostomy on 
the right.

CXR ___:
FINDINGS: 
Calcified pleural plaques bilaterally, correlate with prior 
asbestos exposure. Are small right pleural effusion.  Shallow 
inspiration accentuates heart size. Normal pulmonary 
vascularity, no evidence of edema.  Bibasilar opacities, likely 
atelectasis superimposed with pleural calcifications.  
Aspiration or pneumonia cannot be excluded.  No pneumothorax.
IMPRESSION: 
Calcified pleural plaques, correlate with prior asbestos 
exposure. Small right pleural effusion.  No pulmonary edema. 
Bibasilar opacities, likely atelectasis, consider aspiration or 
pneumonia if appropriate.

TTE ___:
The left atrial volume index is severely increased. No atrial 
septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. The estimated 
right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. There is moderate symmetric 
left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is 
moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with 
near akinesis and small aneurysm of the distal third of the 
ventricle and hypokinesis of the inferior wall. The remaining 
segments contract well. Quantitative (biplane) LVEF = 31 %. Left 
ventricular cardiac index is depressed (<2.0 L/min/mw2). No 
intraventricular thrombus/mass is seen. Tissue Doppler imaging 
suggests an increased left ventricular filling pressure 
(PCWP>18mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size is normal with 
hypokinesis of the distal free wall. The aortic root is mildly 
dilated at the sinus level. The aortic valve leaflets are 
severely thickened/deformed. No masses or vegetations are seen 
on the aortic valve, but cannot be excluded as the valve is very 
deformed. There is severe aortic valve stenosis (valve area <1.0 
cm2). No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets 
are mildly thickened. No mass or vegetation is seen on the 
mitral valve. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. No masses or 
vegetations are seen on the tricuspid valve, but cannot be fully 
excluded due to suboptimal image quality. There is moderate 
pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial 
effusion.
IMPRESSION: Severe aortic valve stenosis with deformed valve but 
no discrete vegetation. Moderate left ventricular systolic 
dysfunction with regional wall motion abnormalities consistent 
with multi-vessel CAD. Moderate pulmonary artery systolic 
hypertention. Moderate left ventricular hypertrophy. Mildly 
dilated aorta. Increased PCWP.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ man with a remote history of prostate 
cancer s/p prostatectomy and LN resection c/b LLE lymphedema, 
recent h/o bladder cancer, chronic urinary incontinence 
requiring catheterization now with foley, CAD s/p MI, and mild 
dementia presenting from ___ with ___, right 
hydronephrosis, and ESBL Klebsiella bacteremia/sepsis with 
hospital course c/b NSTEMI, also found to have severe aortic 
stenosis and newly reduced EF (31%).

#Sepsis
#Klebsiella bacteremia
Upon admission, patient was intermittently febrile but 
hemodynamically stable with blood and urine cultures from ___ 
___ growing ESBL Klebsiella. Initially, he was continued on 
Zosyn, which had been started at ___ for undifferentiated 
GNR bacteremia. However, on ___ he was switched to meropenem 
after cultures grew a highly resistant strain of Klebsiella. 
Blood and urine cultures from ___ and ___ at ___ were also 
positive for Klebsiella. By ___ he was no longer spiking fevers 
and WBC was normal. A midline was placed for continued IV abx 
therapy and he was transitioned to ertapenem at discharge. 

___
#R hydrohephrosis s/p nephrostomy placement
Patient presented to ___ with ___ and Cr elevation to 4.6, 
found to have R hydronephrosis on imaging (thought to be most 
likely due to an obstructing blood clot or edema from recent 
bladder tumor resection). He also likely had a simultaneous 
prerenal insult in the setting of sepsis, also contributing to 
his ___.
Cr improved to 2.7 with IVF at ___. Upon arrival at ___, 
Cr was 2.5.  The morning after transfer to ___ a R nephrostomy 
tube was placed by ___ at the recommendation of his urologist at 
___. The day following drain placement, Cr decreased to 
2.3 and then was down to 1.5 on ___ and 1.4 on ___. He had a 
small amount of blood in the nephrostomy bag on ___. Per ___, 
intermittent mild hematuria is not uncommon in a nephrostomy. 

#CAD/NSTEMI
#HFrEF (newly diagnosed)
#Severe aortic stenosis
On ___ at ___, patient had an acute episode of chest pain 
with EKG changes (T wave inversions) and elevated troponins c/f 
NSTEMI. Cardiology at ___ did not feel urgent left heart 
cath was necessary and started a heparin gtt, metoprolol, ASA, 
and atorvastatin. Upon admission to ___, cardiology was 
consulted and felt demand ischemia (type 2 NSTEMI) was most 
likely. Given low suspicion for acute plaque rupture, the 
heparin gtt was discontinued.  He had a TTE on ___ which showed 
severe aortic stenosis, newly reduced EF (31%), and regional 
wall motion abnormalities including a small LV aneurysm. A left 
heart catheterizaiton was deferred on this admission due to 
recovering ___ but will be considered in the future. He will 
also undergo a work up for possible TAVR as an outpatient. Due 
to akinetic regions of the LV wall and the presence of a small 
aneurysm, he was started on apixaban 2.5mg BID in addition to 
ASA.  He did have hypoxia to high ___ on room air on ambulation 
early on in the admission, received one dose of 40mg furosemide 
PO, and was euvolemic without hypoxia for the rest of the 
admission.

#Toxic metabolic encephalopathy
Per notes, patient has mild dementia at baseline. Has had 
intermittent confusion and altered mental status in the setting 
of acute infection and prolonged hospitalization. Mental status 
improved with treatment of infection. Started sun-downing on 
___ and ___ and was started on quetiapine 25mg QPM starting 
___ with improvement.

#Chronic LLE lymphedema
Stable. No treatment was required.

#L toe pain
Patient reported new pain in left toes. No changes in sensation 
or strength in L foot on exam and no clear erythema of the skin 
or joints. Thought to be related to his chronic LLE lymphedema.

#L ear pain/fullness
Build up of cerumen in L ear canal with no e/o otitis media or 
otits externa on exam. Treated with 4 days of carbamide peroxide 
drops.

#HTN
Antihypertensive medications held in the setting of sepsis.

#Iron deficiency anemia
Hb 9.3 on admission and stable from early ___. Iron studies 
c/w iron deficiency, likely due to poor nutrition versus blood 
loss. Hb trended daily and no transfusions were required.

#Dyspnea:

respiratory symptoms at rest but was dyspneic and desaturated to

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. You were admitted 
because of an infection in your urine that had spread to your 
blood. You were treated with intravenous antibiotics and this 
infection improved. You should continue taking the IV antibiotic 
through ___.

The infection may have developed because of an obstruction of 
urine outflow from the right kidney. You had a tube placed on 
your right side to drain the fluid building up in the right 
kidney. After this drain was placed, your kidney function 
improved. This drain should stay in place for 6 weeks.

You also had an echocardiogram (ultrasound of the heart) because 
of the heart attack you had when you were at ___. 
This test showed that there is severe narrowing of one of the 
heart valves, which may be causing you to feel short of breath 
when walking. We would like to you to follow up with cardiology 
for further evaluation.

Please seek immediate medical attention if you have chest pain, 
shortness of breath, weight gain, increased swelling in your 
lower extremities, blood in the urine, or fever greater than 
101.

If you have further questions, please contact your outpatient 
providers.

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team
